title: Kate Silver + Spider discuss BAD's "Learn to Skate" Program // Bay Area Derby 2023

last_post.content:
Our Learn to Skate program is where most of our skaters start. Hundreds – if not thousands – of skaters have come up through BAD. People from all walks have come to Peralta, laced up an old pair of quads, and learned how to stand up on their own eight wheels. They’ve laughed as they’ve fallen, cried as they’ve gotten bruised, and hugged it out when friends helped them up.

Here’s Spider and me talking about why this program is so important to us.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sXhyq_PmV3A

This is a PBS documentary about Harvey Wiley, the guy responsible for the creation of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. In the 1800s, the unfettered magic of "free markets" had led to things like milk laced with formaldehyde, and the "food" industry was slowly poisoning a huge swath of the public. Harvey spent most of his life attempting to rein in these scumbags, with admirable success.

title: Supporting Piggybacked Co-Located Leisure Activities via Augmented Reality

last_post.content:
Third #CHI2023 :chi: presentation from our group is a playful exploration of how to leverage mobile AR to support leisure. This one piggybacks on existing fun things people do with people and pets.

Examples: make music with your cat or meditate with friends

Project led by our fantastic former Snap intern: Sam Reig (now on the academic job market)

Head to Hall F, Wed, Apr 26 | 17:31 - 17:45

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Lbk_fysRjM

Paper:
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3544548.3580833

Today's first #CHI2023 :chi: @princeton contribution is an honorable mention 🎖️ paper about what people want from their AI explanations.

Key finding: people with low-AI knowledge but high-domain expertise want XAI so they can help it work better in the future.

Work led by the awesome @sunniesuhyoung presented at Wed, Apr 26 | 09:00 in Hall D

Paper: Understanding How Explainability Can Support Human-AI Interaction
https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03735

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IcVsi5-ON4Y

TODAY IN QUEER TV HISTORY

MARCH ON WASHINGTON COVERAGE - 4/25/1993

Today is the anniversary of the massive March on Washington for Lesbian, Gay & Bi Equal Rights and Liberation, the 3rd and largest such march.

This video contains excerpts of ABC's GOOD MORNING AMERICA, which went out as people were lining up for the march. Much of the show was devoted to "gay rights" and this protest. Clips include interviews with historian Eric Marcus and march cochair Nadine Smith.

TV networks had largely ignored the 1979 National March on Washington for Lesbian & Gay Rights, and most misinterpreted the 1987 one as exclusively an AIDS protest, but coverage of this 1993 march was more extensive and accurate.

By the time of the Millennium March in 2000, great progress had been made in merging the LGB rights movement with the trans rights movement, and that protest dealt with both sexual orientation and gender identity.

https://youtu.be/zCZWWeS-m5A

#MediaStudies #lesbian #gay #bisexual #queer #LGBTQ

title: Clock (Words by William Shakespeare, Read by Neil Gaiman, Music by FourPlay StringQuartet)

last_post.content:
The Neil Gaiman & FourPlay String Quartet album Signs of Life is released this Friday!

In advance to that, we've released another track: this time the words are by William Shakespeare, read of course by @neilhimself

For the music, we started with a metronome ticking at 60bpm, and improvised a soaring postrock crescendo around it.
And our violinist Lara Goodridge created an incredible video.

Proud of this, please check it out!

Today I publish a rather simple #Space #Science with #Python video on "Sample Weights".

Our Cassini CDA Calibration fit from last time did not consider the input data distribution. In fact, mostly people don't do that when conducting regression tasks. But ... well ... you should (either by over- / under-sampling, or sample weights).

Our case is too simple for that (in fact). But it is best practice nonetheless #ml #ai #keras #coding #programming

https://youtu.be/x6kDzp1thHo

title: No Mow May? No Mow April? Low Mow Spring?

last_post.content:
If you have a lawn, and would like it to help #bees, there are a few things you can do less. Don't use pesticides. Don't use herbicides. Don't mow for the first few weeks when the grass begins to grow. This will allow wildflowers such as clover, violets, and self-heal to feed #pollinators. In England, and many parts of the US, this time is May. So this practice is commonly known as #NoMowMay.

Watch this and learn much more about No Mow May:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihXAwIcBoJ4

One of the topics this summer in our #CulturalHeritage Centre will be natural #cordage, #fibres from nature and the old #traditions of these plants: #brambles, #nettles, #hemp or #linen. @ClaireFromClare @natureworks There are different regional traditions and materials but the #skep #hives are quite common in many countries. My photo is from our Alsatian farm museum and #CulturalHeritage centre. Here is a skep maker in GB showing the technique: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vLITXe_xvM8
The shape developed with experience. The bees liked it, it was weather protected. The hook shows that this one was suspended under the barn/house eaves. People lived with their #bees very close.

I’m just so proud of the messages from the national 4-H organization about diversity and inclusion. It honestly got me a bit tearful tonight.

As a closeted gay youth in a rural area, I didn’t have many chances to experience diversity of any kind. I felt alone.

4-H gave me the chance to travel, see the world is much bigger than I imagined, and taught me there is a place for everyone. I’m forever thankful. 🌈🍀❤️

title: Everyday wisdom from Wired magazine's founding editor

last_post.content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wXML1wXlVmI #gaming #advice #mmo #kevinkelly

If you went to Carnegie-Mellon in the late 1980s, you probably took a Pascal course, like 15-111, that was taught with the #Pascal Genie, a "structured editor" that allowed programmers to write syntactically valid Pascal programs without worrying about questions like "Did I forget a semicolon?" Older folks used the #VAX 11/780 version, younger folks used it on a Mac.

I managed to find a copy of it to run in emulation, and walk through it in this video, while writing a program that would absolutely get an F from Phil Miller and Mark Stehlik. Please check it out and share with people you think might be interested

https://youtu.be/FXx1JGibSz4

I'm a bit nervous posting this since both @psu_13 and @kvd worked on the Genie and I probably made 50 mistakes in this video that they will be able to correct.

#retro #retrocomputing #programming

He went through the discovery in the Dominion case, pulled out the most egregious lies and admissions and then trained AI voice software to sound exactly like the hosts.

It's not the same as hearing them testify live at trial but it's the next best thing.
